14213.content:
Harry awoke to a tapping sound. Not quite conscious, he began his usual routine of rolling off of the floor mat in his cupboard to get the door only to tumble over the end of his new bed with a startled yelp. Wincing at the sting in his elbows and knees, Harry quickly scrambled up and moved to face the door.

It was at this point that he realized two things. First, that it was still very dark. And second, that the tapping was coming from his bedroom window. Harry quietly padded over to the glass pane, and stared dubiously at the fluffed-up owl perching just outside. It glared back with what he'd swear was an impatient look, and stuck out a skinny little bird leg that...seemed to have an envelope tied to it.

Harry considered his options for a moment, including going back to bed, as it was far too early in the morning for something like this to be happening. He almost immediately decided that this was the coolest thing that had ever happened to him and that he didn't really care if the owl outside was supposed to come to his room or not. He quickly slid up the lower pane and watched with a grin as the owl struggled to fit through the tiny opening.

He laughed a bit as the owl squeezed down, but couldn't fit through as every time it lost balance it flared its big wings and became too wide for the opening. The owl glared again, and shuffled as if about to leave. Biting his lip, Harry did the bravest thing he'd done so far this morning and thrust his arm out the window. The bird made no move to peck him, and allowed him to remove the letter without difficulty.

Hurrying over to his desk, Harry flicked on the lamp and started in surprise at seeing the same green ink, the same odd paper as the envelope he'd gotten in the mail.

Harry Potter
The Littlest Bedroom

Harry huffed a bit at the address; the room seemed plenty big to him, after all! But he put that thought aside quickly as he continued to read the letter with wide eyes.

"I'm...a wizard?" He asked quietly.

What did that even mean? Was it some sort of joke? He didn't think the Dursleys would go to the trouble of getting a trained bird to play a trick on him, and they'd treated the last letter pretty seriously. Harry was very confused. Thinking fast, he scribbled a quick response with far too many questions on the back of the letter and thrust it back out at the bird.

The two had a brief stare-off.

The bird took the letter and flew away.

Harry went back to bed. It really was far too early for this.

Hours later Harry woke for the second time, and continued where he'd left off tidying his room. The Dursleys had been very clear; he was to have the room, but stay out of their way as much as possible, preferably inside the room where they wouldn't have to hear or look at him. And he was on reduced meals for the trouble with the letter. His stomach gave an unhappy grumble at the thought. He couldn't really be sure if he hadn't dreamed what happened before with the owl and the second letter. It seemed like a very nice dream, if a bit strange.

The question of whether or not it was a dream was answered near lunchtime (he hoped) by a smart knocking on his door. Harry quickly hid the construction blocks he'd kept of Dudley's under the bed for safe keeping and scampered over to the door. Opening it, he looked up into the face of a strangely dressed older woman. She ran her eyes up and down him a moment, went back up to his face again, and the she cleared her throat.

"Mr Potter, my name is Professor Minerva Mcgonagall. I'm hear about Hogwarts, and your letter"

Harry blinked, before he started and tried to tug the woman into his room. He wasn't strong enough, but she started walking right away.

"You're...it's real, then?" he asked. "Hogwarts, and magic?"

In answer, the older woman pulled out a stick and waved it at his desk. The mallet he'd used as a splint popped off and the desk leg mended itself. A second wave had the mallet turn into a backrest for the desk chair, and a third was directed right at Harry.

Harry wriggled a bit as his extremely over-sized clothes shrank on him, sliding over his arms and legs until they fit his body. It was a strange feeling. Almost tight after what he was used to; he wasn't sure how he felt about that. But the older woman...the witch had fixed his things!

"I have taken today to explain your heritage to you," Professor Mcgonagall stated briskly, as she seated herself on the edge of Harry's bed. creak

A fourth wave of the wand, Harry guessed, fixed the creaking in his mattress.

"Your relatives were meant to explain things to you themselves; we've...spoken" her tone grew a bit chilly, "about it this morning. You will be allowed to attend Hogwarts and learn magic. However, they have insisted that you keep all school things and activities in your room, and your cousin is not to be told about magic at all. They don't want him to know."

Harry nodded, still mostly wrapping his head around the 'magic is real' bit.

"There was a list of school things," Harry mentioned hesitantly.

"So you want to go, then?" The professor asked, her lips quirking slightly.

"YES!" Harry shouted. "Er, I mean yes please ma'am."

"Good." McGonagall stated, holding out her arm. "Take my arm then, and we will travel by magic to get your things."

No sooner had Harry taken her arm then he felt like he was being squeezed through a tiny tube. He found he absolutely hated the feeling. The world went dark and when light returned he and the professor appeared inside a red stone square in a wide open building with a pop.

McGonagall explained that they were in Gringotts, and that between his father's family inheritance and the "Ministry" paying full value for his family home after it was destroyed to be used as a monument, he had enough money to not need to worry about it if he was sensible.

That explanation led to more questions, and by the time they were properly shopping the older woman had told Harry about his parents, the night of their death, and all sorts of other things that he thought to ask about. She guided him through the shops, letting him buy the odd extra item but mostly telling him with a frown 'not to be too silly with his money' when he started toward the next shiny, noisy, or extremely expensive object.

An oddly loud rumble from his stomach saw the two of them seated in the Leaky Cauldron, where Harry shocked himself by polishing off a full adult meal with dessert and an extra side. McGonagall only said he looked too skinny anyway, and after he'd sheepishly admitted the Dursleys weren't providing much in food she'd quickly taken him back to the alley to pick up a magical cold box for his bedroom and stocked it with healthy meals. She'd even let him buy an irresponsible (her words) amount of Florean's Ice Cream for snacks.

Harry's one request at the end of the day was to not "apparate" home; he'd rather never feel squeezed like that ever again. He thought the Knight bus was even more fun to ride than the goblin carts.

His school shopping done at last, a much happier Harry was returned to his room and given all of his school things with a stern warning from McGonagall to study ahead a bit in his subjects to make a good start at school.

After she left, Harry cheerfully chucked his school books in a pile for later and had an ice cream.
14213.title: The Koi who Lived and the Alley Cat

142132.content:
Harry sighed as he felt his stomach grumble; obviously he'd spoiled it somehow, and turned it into a demanding creature. Stretching a bit, he set down his quill and flexed his hand out, shaking the cramps out of his fingers. Why Hogwarts demanded an outdated writing tool that required so much fine control in the fingers was beyond him. With a sigh, he rose from his chair and ambled over to his cold box for a morning snack.

He didn't think he'd turned full Dudley, but he was beginning to think his cousin didn't just get his appetite from Uncle Vernon. Ever since getting back from Diagon Alley, Harry had made a promise to eat when he was hungry, and to eat until he was full; a big change from how the Dursleys had treated him, and one his stomach had really seemed to appreciate. On the other hand, he found it a bit odd that his stomach, long used to going to bed without supper and breakfasts of single slices of toast and marmite, would turn around and demand a full english breakfast every morning. And a mid-morning meal. And a big lunch. And a meal at tea time. And an afternoon meal, and dinner, and a midnight snack.

Anyway, second breakfast was obviously in order, so Harry cracked the coldbox...and saw the back wall. He blinked, looked again, and slowly closed the box. Opening it again, he saw that he really was on the last of the food; the only thing left in there was a chocolate cake sent from Hogwarts for his birthday last week. The cake was large enough to have needed most of the second shelf for storage, which Harry supposed should have been a clue at the time that he was emptying the cold box alarmingly fast. Harry had been saving it for sentimental reasons; he was sure it would taste wonderful, but he really enjoyed looking at his first real birthday present.

Harry lugged the heavy plate to his desk and pondered the problem as he idly dipped a fork into the gift. His eyes briefly lit up at the taste - it was delicious - before he focused on the problems at hand.

Problem one: where was he putting all of this food?

With a brief, horrifying image of his head on Dudley's body, Harry dropped the fork (a large section of the cake was missing) and rushed to the first floor bathroom. Shutting the lock with a firm turn, he shrugged off his shirt and checked his reflection in the mirror.

The first thing he noticed was he was not fat. Banishing his Dudley-shaped nightmare from his mind, Harry spent some time critically studying his reflection. His ribs were no longer visible, as they used to be, and his stomach looked to be level with his chest, instead of slightly caved in. He gave his side a poke, giggled at the sensation, and then relaxed as he didn't see any ominous jiggling. Definitely not fat, then. But not skinny either.

Harry beamed as he tossed his shirt back on and went back to his desk. Problem two, then: he'd need more food. Harry may have been shocked at himself with how much he was eating, but if he wasn't turning into the family's third blob monster, he really wanted to keep up with the regular meals. It would be best, he decided, to go back to Diagon Alley and get groceries there. He was familiar with the area, he knew where to go to get what he needed, he had wizard money to buy things with...and he wanted ice cream.

Harry nodded as he resolutely set down the fork, deciding to save the rest of the cake for...the cake was gone.

Harry looked from the cake plate, which had to be almost a foot around, to the crumbs (barely any) left of the cake, and down at his still-flat stomach, which felt almost like it was purring. Well, that settled that. He definitely needed more food.

Deciding he'd like to look nice for his trip, Harry grabbed the fitted shirt and trousers the professor had magicced for him, and slipped it the top over his head. And tugged. Frowned. Tugged again. The neck hole popped over his head, scraping his ears, and gripped his neck tightly. Wriggling, he managed to get one arm through an arm hole, but that pulled the whole thing to that side and he couldn't get his hand out through the other. Glancing down, frustrated, he saw that there was a solid inch or two of bare skin showing under the hem. Huffing, he yanked the shirt off (It did not want to go over his head this way, either) and turned to the trousers. A minute of stumbling, hopping, and cursing later, Harry gave this up as a bad job. The button was not going to reach, and his ankles showed. It was like the clothes had shrunk in the wash, or maybe the magic was still working on them.

Or maybe....

Harry shook his head and grabbed some of his school robes. They were fitted, too, and he was going to a wizard area, so they'd be fine. For a moment, he found himself struggling with those as well, but after a second the clothing seemed to relax on his frame, and hung down just as perfectly as when he'd bought them.

There. Obviously the thought he'd started having about why his other clothes were too small was silly. If the robes still fit, then the professor must have made a mistake and left the shrinking on. Good thing it was happening slowly then, it would have been really embarrassing to have burst out of his clothes in the middle of his shopping trip!

Grinning a bit at the image, funny since it hadn't really happened, Harry made quick work of sneaking out of the house, finding a secluded location and hopping the bus to the Leaky Cauldron. Tom gave him a nod, but didn't seem to be paying enough attention to recognize him in particular, and the crowds were heavy enough that he'd blend in fine. He did spot a number of other kids around his own age, looking to buy first wands and loudly chattering about going to Hogwarts. It looked like he wouldn't be the only short person in his class; most of the kids he spotted were around his size.

Harry decided to take care of his necessary shopping first, as he pictured Professor Mcgonagal's stern expression and remembering her warnings about money. Carefully jostling his way through the crowds, he did his best to ignore any tempting signs, passing Magorium's Magical Instruments (Musical and Technical! All that whizzes, zips, and tweets!) and Madam Malkin's (Finest robes for Hogwarts! Enchanted to let out their own seams!) and very carefully not looking at the ice cream parlor.

It didn't take him long at all to pick up enough food to refill the cold box, and as the previous trip got him halfway through the holiday, it should be enough to get him to Hogwarts this time. The grocer even spelled it to stay cold all day, and to fit into one bag. With a whole day ahead of him, Harry decided to do the proper thing and have fun out in the alley, instead of cooping himself up in his room all day. Grinning, he slid into a booth at Florian's and ordered a triple banana split. His stomach grumbled. He ordered two.
142132.title: A Second Helping of Magic

choices: The Littlest Bedroom Gets a Lot Littler
1421322.content:
After polishing off two triple sundaes....Harry felt a bit sick. Maybe Mr Fortescue had been right to give him a dubious look and cheerful warning when he'd taken Harry's order. Well, Harry thought to himself as he slowly swayed out of the ice cream parlor, too late now. He hiccuped a bit as he thought over how to spend his day. Obviously he was staying the magic alley full of wonder; why in the world would he willingly go back to Privet Drive right away?

Gringotts was right out. What looked like a small army of goblins was camped outside the doors, and there was an absolutely ridiculous queue of irritated-looking witches and wizards snaking through the camp, being checked over and over before even getting to the doors. The owner of Magorium's Instruments told him there'd been a robbery some time back, and the whole bank was on lock down.

So...no shopping spree, then. Harry still had a bit of pocket money, but he'd already spent a good bit on more food, and he supposed this was just a sign that he should listen to Professor Mcgonagall, and that a giant shopping binge wouldn't end well. He looked a bit forlornly at the Magical Menagerie...he thought it might be cool to get a pet, maybe a magical fish or something. Then again, he was on thin ice with the Dursleys anyway.

Window shopping was the order of the day. Talking with several of the shop owners, Harry discovered that, for the most part, the wizarding world had an 'artisan economy', which meant that most of the goods were hand-made by a witch or wizard that had worked out special, unique spells or properties for their products, and a lot of the goods out there were custom made for the customer. Harry thought it sounded really cool; maybe he could open a shop when he got out of school.

He saw some really cool, unique items for sale; odds and ends that had been made to test new spell, or had been made on order but then never purchased. He saw a saxophone that animated brooms to sweep up while it was played, a compass that he was promised pointed to his greatest desire, three different talking mirrors, a pair of shoes that let you walk on walls, and a thousand other wonderful things. Harry thought, just maybe, he'd come back next summer and ignore the professor's advice...just a little.

He was recognized, twice. Once was by the owner of a magical nick-knack shop. Hearing he lived with muggle relatives - who he didn't particularly like - the man had given him, at no charge, a doorknob with a minor muggle-repelling ward on it. He told Harry that if he replaced his bedroom knob with the new one, any time his relatives wanted to bother him, they wouldn't make it past the door. The second time was by a fellow shopper; an older woman in Flourish and Blotts glimpsed his scar as he was skimming a book on jinxes; she'd just given him a pat on the head, called him "dear" and continued shopping.

After a nice dinner at The Leaky Cauldron, Harry caught the Knight Bus back home. He'd made it past the park when his day took a bit of a down-turn.

"Well, look at that, it's Potter!"

Harry stalled, looking into the park warily. Dudley and several of his regular 'friends' were lounging on some of the older equipment. It looked like one of them had been drawing dirty pictures on the slide with a marker. One of them had definitely spotted him, though, and he had their full attention.

"Is he wearing a dress?" Pier's hooted with laughter, pointing.

Harry turned red, embarrassed. He couldn't believe he'd forgotten that he was wearing robes! The whole group was laughing, now. What was he even supposed to say? Did this count as revealing magic?

"Er...it's my school uniform." Harry answered, trying for a slightly haughty tone. Steeling his nerves, Harry started a casual march toward Privet Drive. The worst they'd done was laugh; he could put up with that, and he'd be out of here in less than a month anyway.

"Hey Dudley," Piers turned towards Harry's cousin, eyeing Harry out of the corner of his eye and frowning. "Didn't you say Potter was getting shipped off to some private school in Scotland next month?"

Dudley grunted a bit, nodding.

"Yeah, some old bat came by last month and said he was going; his parents set it up when he was a baby or something."

Harry tried to keep an eye on the group. He wasn't too far from the house now; while Vernon and Petunia would definitely take Dudley's word over his about any fighting, they'd never let him do anything serious right under their noses. Vernon had opinions about hooligans, even if he didn't notice his kid was one.

"That's so sweet," Piers cooed mockingly. He paused, as if he'd had an idea. "Of course, that means we don't have much time to pay him back for ruining that zoo trip."

"Yeah..." Dudley drawled, as he started walking toward Harry. The others followed.

"Yeah," he said again as he started walking faster. "And he got us kicked out before we could see the lizards. And he scared off the fish...I heard the zoo got a really big one about then, too. It was on the telly; they've got, like, a six foot long koi fish in there."

"It's your own fault we got kicked out!" Harry shot back, hopping backwards and turning to take off faster. Unfortunately, he still wasn't used to moving in robes and he tripped mid-turn and landed hard with a loud "OOF!"

"What's wrong, Potter?" Piers sneered as Harry found himself surrounded. "Hard to run away in a dress?"

Harry hastily scrambled to his feet, looking around nervously. He frowned. Something seemed...off. Dudley's crew were still looming menacingly around him, but they seemed...less loomy. He blinked a bit in surprise when he noticed that Piers, who'd always been the smallest and rattiest of the group, wasn't any bigger than him. His thoughts from that morning came back to him; maybe he had grown a bit this summer.

By this point, he was completely boxed in, and Harry accepted that even if he had gained an inch or two, that didn't mean much compared to most of this group's hulking forms, or to being outnumbered, or having to fight in an unfamiliar dress...robe! It was a robe!

Gritting his teeth, and deciding that if he never had to see any of these punks again, he'd rather leave making a statement. He'd treasure the shocked look in Piers' eyes as he decked him in his pointy nose forever.

Hours later, Harry was in his room, an ice pack on his face, grounded for the rest of the summer, and missing a baby tooth. Weirdly, he felt content. Sure, he was in a lot of pain, and covered in bruises, but he'd made those punks bleed too for once. He had a cold box full of food to last until Hogwarts, a magic Dursley-repelling doorknob, and he was less than a month away from leaving Privet Drive and going to learn magic!

His only regret was that he kind of wanted to go visit the zoo again, now. He wanted to see that new fish.
1421322.title: A day in the alley

choices: Harry's change alarms McGonagall; he needs a checkup
McGonagall's seen this before; it should stop on its own
14213221.content:
Locked up in his room, the days leading up to his Hogwarts trip blurred together, and so between sleeping, eating and studying, Harry marked the weeks by personal firsts.

Four weeks out from the big day, he managed to light his wand for the first time. Lumos wasn't too difficult, once you figured out the trick, but Harry hoped he could learn magic faster with a proper teacher. Harry also took a pair of Dudley's old trousers and cut the leg hems to fit just right. After, he placed them in front of his closet door next to the magically sized pair for comparison. The roughly cut pair was definitely a bit longer. He planned to check the magic pants for any shrinking later. Deciding to test the other half of his theory, he also stood against the closet door and made a careful line over his head in pencil.

Three weeks out, Harry took a break and unscrewed the magic doorknob from his door and walked around the house holding it in front of him. He spent a wonderful afternoon watching his Aunt Petunia purse her lips and stalk toward him, only to go glassy-eyed and sort of wander off in a daze every time she got close. She probably wanted to know why he'd do something as ridiculous as wander around holding a doorknob. Toward evening, he parked himself on Dudley's bed and nibbled his way through his cousin's entire stash of candy bars, offering a chocolaty smile whenever one of the Dursleys charged in to remove him.

Two weeks out Harry paused while working on his quill writing as he felt his toes tap the floor under his desk chair. Leaning over out of curiosity, he bent his knee and slowly dragged his big toe along the grain of the floor boards; something he'd never been able to do while sitting in that chair before. Humming thoughtfully, he slowly stood up out of his chair - very deliberately not hopping, as he suddenly didn't have to - and made his way over to the closet door.

The magic trousers didn't look any smaller compared to the larger pair, but when Harry slipped the bigger ones on he could clearly see some ankle. (The waist was still too big, of course. Dudley was a wide, wide boy.) The smaller fitted (used to be fitted) pair wouldn't close at the waist, and Harry could wrap his hand around the skin they showed above his feet. He was shocked at the difference, but he'd been somewhat prepared for it when he saw the pencil mark on the closet door floating slightly below his eye level.

During his last week, Harry did three things. First, he tried on his Hogwarts clothes again. Now that he was paying attention, he was able to see the clothes lengthening on him. However, unlike last time they stopped an inch or so too soon...in pretty much every direction. The bottom of the robe was too far off the ground, the sleeves were too short, and the whole outfit pinched a bit.

The second thing Harry did naturally followed; he went out and bought new clothes. He threw on the nicest of Dudley's old things, which were now barely long on him even if they were too wide, and jammed his feet into the pair of his cousin's shoes that he'd saved. Harry was glad he'd decided to do that, even if when he'd planned to grow into them he'd pictured more of a 'few years' kind of thing instead of a few weeks. The nice shoes he'd bought for Hogwarts wouldn't slip on at all; he even had to go barefoot as he'd apparently outgrown child-size socks.

Fortunately he was now a regular pro with the Knight Bus. Madam Malkin was very apologetic, and convinced she must have sold him badly hemmed robes. He got a new set at a discount, and she even threw in an extra few inches of growing room "just in case" (she'd pinched his cheeks at that point...Harry had mixed feelings). He stopped at Gringotts (they were open again, though security was still higher than he remembered) and he stocked some more food. Apparently the amount of food that lasted him four weeks the first time only made it for three the second.

The last thing Harry did was - of course - go to King's Cross and get on the Hogwarts Express. Harry had been too excited to wait at Privet Drive and had taken off just after dawn. The Knight Bus staff were happy to explain the barrier to him when he admitted he didn't know where he'd find a "Platform 9 3/4" anywhere, so he'd spent exactly twenty seconds on the muggle side of the station. He'd just finished claiming a compartment as his personal territory when someone knocked on his door. Before he could even think about getting up the door swung open and a large ball of frizzy hair attached to a girl swept in.

"Oh hello, is there room in this compartment?" The hair asked.

"Er..." Harry looked around at nobody and wondered if that was a real question.

"Oh, sorry," she continued without yet stopping for air, "I only wanted to know if I was allowed; are the first years all supposed to sit somewhere else?"

"I'm a first year." Harry offered, bemused.

Hearing that, the girl stopped to breathe (this oddly made Harry feel a bit less like he was suffocating) and looked him up and down.

"Oh. I'd thought...well you're rather tall then aren't you? Simple mistake. I suppose I'll just sit in here then, and if we're both in the wrong place we'll find out together. I'm Hermione Granger by the way."

As the girl...Hermione...kept talking, she dragged a large rolling suitcase in behind her and slid it into the space under the seat opposite from Harry. Sitting at the end of her seat, she thrust out her hand with an expectant look.

It took Harry a few seconds to realize she wanted to shake hands.

Over the next hour, the two gradually made a bit of conversation, with Hermione doing most of the talking. Harry found he didn't mind too much; spending nearly two months more or less by himself had made him a bit quieter, and having someone to listen to was a nice change. Fortunately before he got tired of listening (he wasn't sure if he could make her stop talking) a round-faced boy named Neville joined the group and drew her attention.

Other students came and went, a small army of redheads swarmed the train at the last minute, and Hermione and Neville swept out the the compartment in a flurry of frizzy hair to find his pet toad. Some blond ponce knocked on his door and asked about Harry Potter; Harry just shrugged and pointed him toward the back of the train. An hour in, Hermione and Neville came back with Trevor in hand to see Harry calmly eating his second breakfast, which he had packed just for the trip. Both of them were a bit bemused when Harry immediately bought a small candy mountain when the trolly came by and passed some out to share.

Harry shrugged a bit as he bit into a chocolate frog. He could make room for dessert if he could share it with (he hoped) friends. Besides, apparently he was a growing boy.
14213221.title: Granger on a Train

142132212.content:
Harry's first reaction to seeing "Mr Hagrid," the extremely large man in charge of the introductory boat ride, was a bit of alarm. Surely not all wizards got so big; he'd seen a lot of wizards over the last month and most seemed pretty normally-sized. Maybe it was just Mr Hagrid.

Maybe it was him, too?

Harry craned his neck about as the boats floated themselves toward a hidden castle gate. As Hermione and Neville were both smaller than him; it wasn't hard - between staring wide-eyed at the amazing magical castle - to pick up a new frame of reference. He saw a couple other kids his size; a red-headed boy with freckles was probably taller, though he looked a bit stringy, and two boys following that blond ponce from the train were absolutely massive. Most of the other children, however, seemed to reach somewhere between his chin and his nose. Surrounded by people his own age, Harry came to the conclusion that he was, indeed, tall.

Neat.

As he disembarked with his future classmates, Harry mused a bit about what this might mean for his future. He wasn't sure if he wanted to end up Hagrid-size; that seemed like it might be inconvenient, though on the other hand Harry doubted anyone went up to the man looking for trouble. As McGonagall steered the group into a waiting area (she gave him a bit of a double-take) he decided he'd just have to ask somebody if he kept growing. Maybe if he caught himself looking eye-to-eye with the red-head.

He was very impressed with the magic singing hat. (The song, not so much, but the hat was bril.) He was double-impressed when it had the good sense to send both of his new friends into the same House, making his own sorting much more convenient for everyone. He'd barely had a chance to see if Neville was able to save him an extra seat near him and Hermione when McGonagall called his name.

He quickly decided that most wizards did not know how to whisper properly.

"Potter?

"The Harry Potter?"

"Well, he's a tall one, isn't he?"

"Peas and carrots."

Confused and slightly hungry over the last one, which came from his future table (he was very confident about this), Harry barely registered when the professor asked him to see her after the feast. Then there was a hat on his head. Unlike several of the others before him, it seemed to fit his head a bit better than average.

"Hmm..." muttered a voice in his ear. "Yes, it is important to have a properly-sized head. Most of you lot are all ears; barely anything to hold onto. You want to be with your new friends?"

"Yes, please." Harry offered.

"Rather loyal of you, that's a strong Hufflepuff trait, and you seem to take promises seriously too, I've hardly ever seen such dedicated magic..."

"Um, what?" Harry asked, confused. He didn't really understand any of that. "Look, if I want to be with my friends, don't use that to separate us! That's not fair!"

The hat snorted a bit. "Well, that was definitely brash. And quite a bit of righteous anger, too; don't like people stepping on others' toes, bossing them around?"

"It isn't right." Harry offered, firmly.

"Well, in that case, please continue fighting for justice, honor, and so on. Just make sure to mind where you step in-"

"GRIFFINDOR"

The rest of the sorting passed in a bit of a blur for Harry, as he made space between his two cheering friends. The feast passed in a blur of a different kind. One with apparently endless food.

"Blimy"

Harry looked up from his plate, offering a shy smile when he locked gazes with twin red-heads on the opposite side of the table. The two seemed to be glancing between him and the red-head kid his own age who was a few seats down.

"Which one you think will stop first?" Left twin asked.

"Well, Potter's up five plates to four, and even giant eleven-year-olds only have so much room in there." Right twin answered.

"True, true." Left twin rubbed his chin. "On the other hand, Ron usually only has four plates at home."

"What?" Ron - Harry assumed this was young red-head's name - glanced up at the twins suspiciously.

They offered him giant identical grins, that only got wider as his face paled and he went back to his plate.

"A sickle on Potter." Left twin offered.

Hermione scoffed as she pushed her dessert around on her plate.

"Oh really," she muttered, "hardly setting a good example, gambling."

She gave Harry a curious look, though. One that, now Harry was paying attention, he saw Neville shared.

"Do you always eat this much?" She asked.

Harry shrugged, quickly washing down the last food that was on his plate.

"Lately, yes." He offered, eyes locking on a nearby platter with treacle tart. Target acquired. Hesitating, he checked his friends' expressions before he reached out for a scoop. He kept an eye on them as he slowly added two more.

Neither of his friends seemed offended, just a bit surprised. The twins just changed some money around; so that probably meant Ron had stopped eating. Harry hummed contentedly as he polished off the treat; he hadn't had a chance to eat many good deserts besides ice-cream, which he may have over-purchased in the last month. Harry was just glad that he'd long-since mastered the art of fast, but polite eating. There hadn't really been any other way to avoid both a scolding from Aunt Petunia and Dudley stealing his food.

Professor Dumbledore offered a list of school announcements as Harry finished dessert; the comment about painful death waiting in the school caused him to choke briefly, and he'd had to sip water for a few minutes afterward. It was only after he and the other students rose to head off to their new common room that Harry felt and hand on his shoulder and looked to the side to find Professor McGonagall looking back at him with an expectant expression.

"Mr Potter, if you would come with me please."

It was not a request, so Harry shortly found himself back in the pre-sorting waiting room, sitting on the sorting stool, with his new head of house looking him up and down. He couldn't help fidgeting a bit under her gaze, and he blushed a bit as his stomach audibly purred.

"First Mr Potter," the stern woman offered him a tight smile, "you are not in trouble. However, as you are - I'm sure you've noticed - considerably larger than you were several weeks ago, I will need to perform a quick check-up to rule out a few causes."

"Er," Harry shifted a bit on the stool. "I did notice; and I don't really know why it's happened...are you the school nurse as well?"

"No." McGonagall offered simply as she pulled out her wand. "I'm not confident that we need to involve her just yet, and the sorts of things for which I am checking you are under my particular field of expertise. You're hardly the first student I've seen who's body decided to impersonate a dragon hatchling before school opened. Usually, it just means that student has a strong aptitude for Transfiguration. You'll find most of the more talented in the field have very distinct or idealized features; sometimes being introduced to magic can trigger an episode like this."

Harry mulled that over a bit; he knew in theory what Transfiguration was, he'd spent most of his time skimming his school books after all. A thought occurred to him as he remembered the last time he'd seen this witch do magic, and he hunched back on the stool.

"Are you going to shrink me?" He asked, voice slightly higher pitched, as he eyed her wand warily.

McGonagall smiled, and laughed slightly.

"Most definitely probably not. That's the first test." Without any further warning, the professor muttered a long string of odd words and tapped Harry rather hard on the head.

Nothing happened.

"Well," McGonagall offered, "you're not a Metamorphmagus, or you likely would have shrunk."

Harry just nodded frantically, even though he had no idea at all what a Metamagus was. He winced as a second tap followed; he wondered if that would start to leave a mark.

This time, though, Harry looked down to see his whole body glowing slightly. The professor didn't seem particularly surprised.

"Well," she offered briskly as she helped Harry to his feet. "You've transfigured yourself; it's an unconscious, permanent effect. I'm not concerned at the moment, as it's rather similar to most cases I've run into. If I had to guess, you probably wanted to outgrow your cousin. From what I saw in your home, that does not surprise me. It does show a strong aptitude for my subject, so I will be expecting excellent work from you. As unstructured self-transforming magic is extremely fiddly it would be best, for the moment, to let it run its course. Likely you'll either slow back down in a month at the most, or you'll just transition into a more ordinary growth spurt; you are at that age."

"I'll make an appointment for you with our nurse for Halloween; that should be simple enough for you to remember. In the meantime, it's definitely time for bed."

Harry couldn't help grinning a bit as he trailed along behind the professor, taking in the wonders around him. He was in a magic castle, he had his very own friends, and he'd just been told that he was going to be bigger than Dudley!

Harry didn't stop smiling even as he fell asleep, tucked into the most comfortable bed in the whole world. Safe, happy, and warm, Harry felt ten feet tall.
142132212.title: Nothing to See Here...

1421322121.content:
Harry blinked, disoriented, as he sat up on his bed. His feet felt weirdly cold, and his legs shifted oddly as he scooted back to sit on his pillow. He felt something rough on his shoulders, and something was digging into his back. Reaching blindly behind himself, he frowned as his fingers curled over a carved wooden surface; the headboard on his new bed. But why was it so low? And why were his feet still cold?

Reaching through his curtains, Harry felt around for the top of his new desk; his confusion increasing as he reached lower and lower until finally his hand lightly smacked onto the surface. He slowly drew his arm back in, feeling the wood grain sliding under his fingers as he looked for his wand. It was close, much closer than he'd thought, and it felt odd in his hand. The wand's grip seemed smaller, he covered the whole area with only three fingers, and it was so narrow that he had to pinch it instead of simply holding on.

"Lumos," he muttered in a raspy voice. He stared down at the end of his four-poster, where the curtains at the foot of the bed were draped over his knees; his calves and feet must be on the other side, sticking out into the open air.

His head was almost touching his bed canopy, and his back climbed past the headboard and up the stone wall of the room.

Quietly, Harry drew his legs in; sitting hunched over his knees, feet in front of him, he took up the entire bed. His surroundings seemed a bit blurry and unclear; likely because he had no glasses on. Harry drew the side curtains open.

Lit by his wand, the entire room was tiny. The other beds were spread through the space, their occupants softly snoring inside. Next to each bed was a tiny desk, and a small wardrobe. Rising to his feet, Harry stumbled slightly as he looked down on the furniture, his shoulders even with the bed canopies and the desks barely reaching his knees.

Sitting on his desk were his glasses. Picking them up with two fingers, Harry quickly realized they were far too small to be of any use. Without them, the room seemed hazy, and it was hard to pin down what things looked like or where they were. Harry set his glasses down.

More curious than afraid, Harry couldn't resist squeezing his way around the room; there was barely space for him to move around, even though the room had felt fairly open and spacious that evening. He bent down and picked up a pair of shoes, tilting his head as he crammed a finger inside and touched the toe. Had these really been on his feet a few hours ago?

A splashing sound drew his gaze to the tower window; big enough to hold a window seat for the students, Harry hunched down and slowly pressed his frame into the space, the seat under his palms creaking alarmingly. Gazing out on the moonlit grounds, Harry saw ripples spreading out on the lake. Suddenly, an enormous fish shot out, arced through the air, and crashed back onto the water with an earthshaking splash.

A Koi fish?

---

"Oi, Potter! It's morning already!"

Harry blinked, rubbing grit out of his eyes, as he took in the giant four-poster bed surrounding him. Daylight lit the room outside, and cast a dark boy-shaped shadow on the curtains. He frowned. He'd been dreaming...he thought. Something about fish? He shook his head to focus; at Hogwarts it would be back to three meals a day; he wouldn't learn anything if he spent all his time thinking about food.

Harry opened his mouth wide, letting out a loud yawn, before swinging his legs over the side and wincing as his feet connected with the cold stone floor. Opening the curtains, he looked up into a wide-smiling freckled face and an outstretched hand.

"Pleased to meet you!" Offered the boy, shaking Harry's hand while Harry tried to work out if he was awake or not yet.

"My name's Weasley, Ron Weasley." He offered, letting go of Harry's hand and gesturing behind him at three other boys who were all going about different morning tasks.

"Over there are Seamus Finnegan and Dean Thomas, and Neville said you'd already met."

"Er, Harry." Harry offered, stretching and toeing around the floor for a pair of slippers.

"Well if I can call you Harry, call me Ron." The boy seemed pleased. "I can't believe I'm finally here, you know? And in Griffindor with the Harry Potter; well, of course you got into Griffindor, m'not surprised about that, and my family's all been lions for ages, so..."

The boy was rocking a bit on his heels at this point, looking slightly self-conscious. The black boy - Finnegan or Thomas - laughed a bit and walked over, offering Harry his hand.

"Don't mind him, Potter. Ron's just pleased to meet you. We met on the train, and he's alright, even if he has mad ideas about what makes a proper sport. He was really excited to meet you after the feast, since you're famous or something. Dunno about that, but you seem alright too. You can call me Dean, Dean Thomas."

"Harry," Harry offered, feeling a bit more confident and awake. Keeping Dean's grip a moment, Harry quickly hoisted himself off the bed and started looking around for his things.

"Blimey, there's two of 'em." Exclaimed the last boy, who must be Finnegan.

Dean quickly retreated back to his area, letting the last, and shortest of the boys in the dorm have a chance to introduce himself. Finnegan didn't offer his hand right away, instead glancing back and forth between Harry and Ron.

"I'm going to feel like a ruddy midget bunking with you two! I mean, it was bad enough yesterday with just this one!" Finnegan grumbled, smiling, as he smacked Ron lightly on the shoulder. Indeed, the top of the boy's head was about level with Harry's shoulders.

"Well, you're titchy." Ron snorted, poking the boy in the forehead. He turned back toward Harry. "This is Seamus Finnegan, wizard, booze-smuggler, and dorm midget."

"Oi!" Finnegan objected, offering Harry his hand. "Call me Seamus. I am a wizard, I do have a few bottles of Butterbeer in my trunk, and I am not a midget. Stringbean over here just got an early start, what with me being born in June. I'm only barely eleven, so there!"

"I was born in July." Harry offered, apologetically.

Seamus gave him a betrayed look.

"Late July," Neville chimed in from his wardrobe.

Harry frowned thoughtfully as Seamus pouted; how did Neville know that?

"Anyway," Ron offered, hopping up to sit on Harry's desk, "we thought we'd wake you up; whatever you were doing with McGonagall yesterday - Neville told us you'd gone off with her - must have taken a while; we didn't get to really meet you, and you slept through all of us waking up."

"Thanks." Harry offered, grabbing his bathroom things and heading to the ensuite. "It shouldn't happen again; too much excitement I suppose."

"No trouble," Seamus offered with a smile as he slipped on his shoes. "We'll wait a bit and all go down together. And if you aren't a morning person, at least it should be safe to have Stringbean over there wake you up."

"Oi! Stop calling me Stringbean!"

"Stop calling me Midget!"

Harry grinned at Dean through the mirror as the two brushed their teeth. Sure, the dorms were a bit more cramped than he'd like, since he had to share the space, but it looked like he'd get on with all of them. He hoped Hermione was having as much luck in the girls' dorm.
1421322121.title: The Koi who Lived and his School

choices: The secret of the third floor
14213221212.content:
Hermione was not having Harry's luck in her dorms, and things didn't improve even as September turned into October. To hear her tell it, her dorm mates were a bunch of flighty scatterbrains who ignored everything she had to say unless they wanted to grill her about "tall dark and handsome."

Harry wasn't really sure how to deal with that; he wasn't really thinking about...dating and stuff yet, but to hear Hermione talk about it, it was all that her dorm mates thought about all the time, and worse they were thinking about him. Apparently he'd made a real impression during the first flying lesson. Neville had almost shot up out of control at the beginning, but Harry had managed to jump up and grab hold of his ankle. To hear the rumors afterward, he'd cleared ten feet easy; Harry didn't think it had been that much, and magic had probably helped, but his classmates had been impressed. Afterward, he'd done so well on his broom that he'd been declared a natural by Madame Hooch, even if he couldn't turn as tightly as some of the small first years.

Wood had already approached him about trying out for reserve keeper next year.

So far, all of Harry's classes were going well, except maybe potions. Between Hermione's talent at research, and Neville's wizarding background, Harry's group of friends managed to finish their schoolwork quickly and without too much trouble (though for whatever reason Hermione often spent extra time going over the required writing).

It also helped that Harry found himself able to focus much better as about three weeks into term his weird, constant hunger went away. It had happened the same day he'd borrowed one of Ron's robes by mistake and realized the bottom hem didn't quite reach the ground. Ron had taken Seamus's ribbing with good humor, and just said that at least since his robes were hand-me-downs, they wouldn't resize if Harry made that mistake again.

Before he knew it, Halloween had arrived.

"Did you know," Neville spoke as he and Harry made their way out of Charms, "that for a while when we were little, a couple nutters wanted to re-name Halloween 'Harry Potter Day'?"

Harry stumbled a bit mid-stride and turned toward his friend with horror.

Seamus snorted from behind them; the shorter boy must have hustled up to join them after he'd turned in his work.

"No worries, Harry. Neville made that up."

"I did not!"

Harry slowed his stride (some more), allowing Seamus to catch up.

"Neville doesn't usually joke that way," Harry gave his friend a puzzled look, and Neville quickly shook his head.

"Must have done," Seamus said, hooking his hands behind his head. "Said it happened when you were little."

Harry sputtered a bit as Neville snorted.

"I...you...I was little, like, last year."

"Show me a photo, with you holding the paper, both for date and scale."

Harry just shook his head and took off for the hospital wing with a few muttered excuses. Things with Seamus had gotten a bit rough a few weeks in; apparently he'd been taking the 'midget' comments a lot more seriously than they'd thought. A prefect had stepped in one evening with him and the short boy had, blushing, confessed that he didn't like the name-calling. There'd been some awkward apologies and shoe scuffing. Harry had decided to share some of his own stories from being picked on back in tinier times. In the end, Seamus had come around, and the dorm had gone back to the fun, teasing atmosphere it had had before, and Seamus had decided to poke a bit of fun at Harry by pretending to believe his 'small' stories were an elaborate lie. (It was a bit hypocritical, but since Harry wasn't actually bothered, he didn't care.)

Besides, Seamus' jokes were just more references to Harry being the biggest boy in his dorm, and Harry had realized he liked being big. Even if some of the attention was embarassing, and he had no idea how to deal with Hermione's dorm mates, nobody picked on him. Nobody called him names, or ignored him. Sometimes if the first years were all working as a group, they looked to him as a leader or protector. It felt...good.

Madam Pomphrey was quick and professional. She did a lot more tests on him, asked some awkward questions about certain body parts, and within ten minutes declared him "perfectly healthy, still (barely) within normal measurements and development standards for his age, and probably done with any magical self-enlargement."

It was as he left for the feast that things got...fuzzy.

Looking back on it later, Harry's memory would be unclear at best. One moment, he was walking down the halls outside of the Hospital Wing, and suddenly the whole world seemed to take on a dream-like quality. The world was hazy, and his thoughts random, with no reason or logic. He almost watched as a passenger while his body turned and started down the nearest staircase toward the dungeons.

His body froze in the first sub-level as he heard many footsteps approaching. After a moment, his arm reached out and tilted a nearby torch sconse. A terribly narrow passage opened in the wall to his left, and his mind balked in horror as his body squeezed itself inside.

As he slithered through the tight corridor, shuffling sideways with stones rubbing against his shoulders, Harry's mind balked at the tightness around him, memories of his tiny cupboard, his towering cousin, and his giant furious shouting uncle flashing behind his eyes. For a moment his mind seemed to clear, but a second wave of horrible dizziness later and he was once more along for the ride.

Escaping the tiny crack of a passage, he found himself in a plain, unfurnished hallway. Ahead of him was a large iron-bound wood door with the Hogwarts crest carved into every panel. Odd symbols were cut into the metal frame. Harry was so fascinated by the doorway that he didn't notice he'd moved until his hands closed over a heavy draw-bar and slid the mechanism open.

Harry's head cleared like he'd been dunked in ice water. Standing behind the now open door was a giant...monster. Towering so high it would have to duck into the hall, massive arms holding what looked like a small tree as a club, and staring right at him.

Harry slammed the door shut. The horrible thing bellowed on the other side, and the door slammed at Harry, his feet skidding back on the stonework. He pushed, and shoved at the door, gritting his teeth, but whatever that thing was, it was just too much for him. With a second slam, this time harder, the door blew open and Harry felt himself lift off the ground as he was launched across the hallway.

Terrified, and desperate, Harry ran at the far wall and wriggled himself back into the tight, horribly tight, passageway. As he scurried through like a frightened little mouse, he shuddered as the club slammed into the stone behind him.

His worried friends found him holed up in his bed, and they were telling stories about a troll somehow getting into the castle. He was too ashamed to say anything. They told him the feast had been moved to the common room, but he wasn't hungry.

The next morning, he woke to a growling stomach.
14213221212.title: Terrible Trolls

142132212121.content:
"What on earth?" Harry mumbled as he moved in front of the washroom mirror.

It was Christmas holiday, and Harry and Ron had the dorm to themselves. This was fine; the two of them got along rather well, and Ron had a great sense of humor (most of the time). At the moment, the Weasly boy was snoring away in his bed, which suited Harry just fine. He didn't fancy trying to explain why he was standing around in the washroom in his shorts.

Harry bent his arm, and watched as his bare-chested reflection copied him. A modest, but very very real, ball of muscle bunched up at his reflections bicep. The boy in the mirror struck a pose, the enchantment taking over for a moment, and flexed his chest and stomach, six small bumps briefly showing up before fading. The mirror-Harry let out a whistle.

"Keep at it, lad! A few years of effort and you'll break hearts!"

Harry scowled, and pulled a face at the mirror before stepping off to the showers. He hadn't put in any effort at all! He'd only done the same things he'd done before the...incident. And hadn't the adults said he wasn't transfiguring himself anymore? He didn't think he'd gotten any taller since Halloween; Ron was still around eye level. (Though maybe the red-head had grown a bit, too...)

Harry paused, and in a fit of whimsy, spun toward the mirror, flexed his arms and growled. He laughed a bit at the image, stuck out his tongue, and continued with his morning.


*********


Harry and Ron were making an effort to explore the castle while the older students were away. So far, Ron had found a secret passage from near Griffindor Tower to the great hall...by slide. Harry was trying to top that, but so far hadn't found anything nearly that cool to share; the best he'd found was a dusty old mirror where the enchanted reflection was always playing with toys. Though where mirror-Harry got a dollhouse that looked like the Dursleys' house on Privet Drive he had no idea.

So today, Harry was determined to find a super-cool secret to show up his friend/rival. He'd find out what was hidden on the third floor corridor!

Harry was already one hall away from the big secret; he'd been psyching himself up to this for some time. Ever since the...incident....with the troll, he'd been having bad dreams, always waking up feeling scared and claustrophobic. He needed to do something brave, and a little stupid, just to prove that he still could.

Startling briefly at an odd sound, Harry froze and looked around. Nothing was in sight. Gulping, he crept up to the forbidden door. A soft tug did nothing. The door was stuck. Gritting his teeth, Harry braced his feet on the wall and tugged, the sleeves of his robes pulling tighter on his arms as he put everything he had into opening the stupid door!

The door didn't budge. Harry huffed, and glared at the door.

- click -

Harry blinked, staring at the door. Did it just...unlock? Cautiously, Harry pulled on the door, and it swung open with ease. Now suspicious, Harry lit his wand and peered into the room from outside. Suddenly the hair on his neck prickled! Acting without thought, Harry dropped to the ground, and felt some invisible force whoosh through his hair and into the room. His wide eyes took in the site of a suddenly very awake, angry, giant dog before the door slammed shut inches from his nose and clicked.

Harry scrambled back from the door on his hands, eyes darting around the corridor. What had brushed his hair? What if he hadn't ducked?!?

As he ran back to the dorms, Harry had two thoughts.

Ron would be super impressed to hear about the giant dog.

And whatever had tried to knock him into the dog's room was much more dangerous.
142132212121.title: Big Dogs

1421322121211.content:
Harry awoke with a startle.

It Had been the first day of classes since the winter break and his experience on the third floor, though much of his wariness had subsided.
Plus, when his housemate heard about his alarming discovery, he officially granted Harry the title of winner in the battle to see who could find the most outrageous thing in the school.
Likewise, since his experiences with the troll AND the massive three headed dog, things had been relatively normal.

Harry was exhausted when he had returned from classes only half an hour before and had decided he was going to take a nap for an hour or two before getting started on work.

Unfortunately, said startling, and rude awakening was his stomach audibly growling.
Seamus, the runt, was peering over from his bed across the room. Meanwhile Harry was filled with a slight sense of anxiety. Though Seamus was none the wiser as he had been gone over winter break, Harry’s appetite had been steadily increasing. And despite no increases in height — Ron still stood at eye level — his shirts had begun to feel tight across his chest, arms, and back. Likewise his pants had taken to hugging his thighs and butt quite tightly,with his shoes seeming altogether too narrow. Fortunately, no one seemed to notice because of his extra large cloaks.
Groaning, and lifting from his bed with a stretch, and quite the loud yawn, Harry peered over at his roommate, and questioned if he’d like to go to a pre-dinner snack in the Great Hall. Though Seamus gave him a slightly confused look, he agreed to proceed, as he too thought he could use a quick snack as a break in his work.

As they proceeded down from Gryffindor common room, Harry began to realize just how much bigger he was than his classmate. His strides his longer, his steps were louder, his hands were thicker, his —His stomach rumbles furiously, and LOUDLY again. Their pace became brisker, with Seamus needing to run to nearly keep up with Harry. When they finally managed to get to the Great Hall Seamus quickly went to grab a few treats for their walk back, but by time he had turned around Harry already had a plate stacked high with all sorts of food, and was clearly planning to take it with them.

“This should tide me over till supper I suppose” Harry said, looking down skeptically at his meal. He HOPED it would.
His partners response was quick and swift, said with almost no input of thought, “Bloody hell Potter! Are you planning on getting as big as Hagrid? Supper is within the hour, and I don’t think I’ve ever managed to eat that much in my life in one sitting”

Harry was slightly taken aback by the response, but quickly recovered. The teachers had TOLD him he hadn’t stppped transfiguring himself, then any further growth would likely be due to plain puberty. PLUS, why shouldn’t he eat if he was hungry, and who was Seamus to stop him. His response was duly applied with little thought as he angrily retorted “Well, at least some of us ARE growing!” He made a swift exit, plate in hand, stuffing his food in his mouth, leaving a stunned Seamus with treat in hand looking after his quickly receding figure.

And while he regretted the way he may have said it, it wasn’t like Harry was about to apologize for getting bigger. Bigger than anyone he knew, everyone he saw, he’d been small his entire life until recently, and he wasn’t about to feel bad about it because some git was jealous.

As he approached the portrait of the fat lady, saying the password while reaching down for more food, he realized his plate was empty. Which he was mildly upset about, until he looked up at the grandfather clock in the common room and realized most people would be departing soon. He found Dean, Ron and Neville as Seamus rolled into the common room. An irrational sense of pride roiled up in Harry as he saw him make his way uncertainly forward, causing him to puff out his chest just a little bit, which resulted, to his surprise in the top button undoing, and causing him to stand just a little taller. With alarm Harry realized Ron now only was up to his nose.

When Seamus finally reached them through the throng of classmates he stayed relatively quiet, and to Harry it seemed as though his friends were waiting for him to make the first move. He liked this. Being looked up to, like a leader. As he pushed through crowd, making eye contact with some seventh years, and looking over the heads of some fourth years, he finally made it to the exit, and they were off to the Hall.

When they arrived Harry was quick to start piling his plate with food. Unlike the first night in which he only barely eeked out more plates than Ron, tonight Harry easily doubled, maybe tripled his intake, with nearly all the other boys in gryffindor staring at him in wonder by the end of the night. What most of them didn’t know, was that he undoubtedly could’ve eaten more.

By time he made it back to the rooms that night, after some light snacking in the common room, all of his roommates were asleep. He attempted to get his pajamas on, but they were tight and uncomfortabke, So he made his way to the bathroom in just his boxers, which at this pony seemed to leave little to the imagination. When he got there he was slightly taken aback by what he saw in the mirror. He looked bigger. Not taller. But thicker, and older ? His arms were big now, as big as grapefruits, and his chest and stomach seemed developed with muscle. His neck was thicker and his shoulders broader. Hell, he even had some hair growing on his chin and upper lip, among other places.

Completely satisfied with himself, Harry made his way back to bed forgetting to brush his teeth. The only thoughts invading his mind as he laid down in bed pertaining to how much fairer a fight he’d have with Dudley when he got back to little winging.

— — — — — — — —

He awoke the next morning to the brisk winter blowing through an open window, and the room empty. As he swung his now cold legs over the edge of the bed and stuck his feet — attempted to stick his feet into his slippers, he realized them were much to short and much to narrow. Hmm that was strange. He quickly made to shower, not glancing at the mirror in his rush.

As he was brushing the water out of his hair with his towel he heard Ron calling his name, alerting him they were headed to breakfast, and asking him where he was. As he exited the bathroom a much shorter body ran into his, flying to the floor, having almost no effect on him.. It was Ron!! Harry extended his hand to help him up and that’s when they both noticed the changes. Harry’s hand eclipsed Rons. On top of this, the top of Ron’s head only met his chin. And as the young wizard looked closer he started to take in the other differences. His legs were thicker. The towels that usually came mid calf on him, now stopped above his knees. His legs and armpits were hairier, with a little patch starting to grow on his chest, which had also ballooned in size. Harry was massive.

Maybe he was on his way to being as big as Hagrid.

Ron’s response said it all though.
“Blimey, what’re you gonna wear”
1421322121211.title: Cold feet and tiny slippers

14213221212112.content:
Harry stood alarmed. Then his stomach audibly grumbled.

"Ah we gotta get food, I'm starving."

"But, but Harry, you're huge, you-you've grown nearly fifteen centimeters. Plus I bet most of your clothes wont even fit you" Ron stumbled through his words. He was at a loss.

"Nevermind that, I'm sure theres something in here that'll fit me" He said while fumbling through his clothes, "I'm hungry, I gotta eat some breakfast" and with that his stomach released yet another audible growl.

Despite his best efforts, it was clear none of his clothes would fit him, as not only were they short, but they also looked like they'd be much too tight. He peered up at Ron.

"You reckon theres anything in the seventh year dormitories I could borrow."

"Harry thats steali--"

"Man, Ron you're starting to sound like Hermione." Harry Said

That quickly shut the boy up, as he followed the tight pajama pants clad preteen up the stairs. They were barely functioning as pants too, as they hugged tightly around his upper calves, and were starting to split at the seem near his butt. As they made their way through the upper year rooms, Harry carefully looked for suitable clothing. By the end of their scrounging harry was looking moderately better for ware. They'd managed to find a larger shirt and pants from one of the larger fifth years. Though they fit him fine across the waste, and were a relatively loose fit, the pants still stopped above his ankles and shirt was simply to short on his arms. It would have to do though. they had managed to find a larger pair of shoes as well, though Harry's feet still felt relatively constricted within them. And with that, his stomach growled for maybe the tenth time.

"Alright Ron we gotta go, i could eat a cow right now"

With the look of hunger shining in Harry's eyes, Ron didn't doubt it. And as they practically ran to the Great Hall, with everyone passing them on their way back to the dormitory Harry went full steam ahead.

Tucking himself into a seat, Harry hurriedly started to pile multiple plates with food. Whether it was treacle tart, bread pudding or even some chicken wings, the boy was continuously eating.

Seven and a half plates later, and Harry finally managed to push himself away from the table.
14213221212112.title: Get breakfast

142132212122.content:
He had to eat. That’s all he knew, as he rolled out of bed the next morning.
He had vague memories of the night before, something about a door and a troll, but the pangs of hunger in his stomach quickly overwhelmed any concerns he may have harbored.
Looking around Harry noticed his roommates also rousing, getting ready for breakfast. He made eye contact with Neville, smiled, and proceeded to get ready before heading down to the great hall.
After tying the lace on his right shoe he stood up and made his way to the door. His hair was still a bit messy, but then again, it usually was.
“You alright there, Harry? You seemed a little out of sorts last night when we got back” Ron said, glancing backwards to his roommate, as they made there way down the stairs towards the common room.
“Just hungry is al—-“ his stomach rumbled loudly, cutting him off, and leading the rest of the boys to break out in laughter. “Just a little hungry, i guess” he sheepishly added.
“You don’t say Potter? I mean you did miss dinner last night, Halloween too, I’m sure my stomach would be rumbling if i missed a meal too” Seamus added, and then under his breath “though probably wouldn’t shake that loud if i had to guess”
“What was that?”
“Oh nothing” the smaller boy added.

15532.content:
Hi, my name is Michael. You might recognize me from the cover of Time magazine a few weeks ago. Of course, you’d be forgiven if you missed me, seeing as I was sitting in the lap of my kid brother Sean. Ya see, he kinda overshadows anyone he’s with, seeing as he’s twenty feet tall.

You haven’t heard about us? Well, let me tell you about how all this started.

It began three years ago, when I was twelve and Sean was ten. We were riding in the back seat of our parents’ Honda Accord, which our Mom was driving, coming back from a wedding of a friend of hers at work. It was an icy night; snow had been falling for a few hours, and the plows and salt trucks hadn’t gotten to the roads yet.

Sean and I were bugging each other in the back seat, as brothers usually do. “Mom, Michael’s crossing the line onto my side of the seat!”

“Mom, Sean's kicking me!”

Mom turned around, “Boys, you better stop fighting, or I--”

Suddenly, the car started to skid. Mom turned around and tried to keep control, but couldn’t. The car spun off the road and into a tree.

The rest of that night was kinda hazy. I remember waking up in the hospital with a splitting headache. A doctor stood over me with a clipboard.

“Hello, Michael, my name is Dr. Parsons. How are you feeling.”

I sat up slowly, rubbing my eyes. “My head hurts.”

“Try not to move too much, Michael. You have a slight concussion, and a few scratches and bruises, but other than that you’re going to be fine with enough rest.”

“W-what happened?” I asked

“Michael, you were in a car wreck. Evidently your car lost control and skidded headlong into a tree. Thank goodness you were wearing your seat belt; otherwise you might have been thrown from the car, and who knows what would have happened.”

“Where’s the rest of my family?”

Dr. Parsons checked her chart. “Your brother, Sean, is in the OR right now. He’s been banged up pretty bad, but we expect him to pull through.”

She paused, and I noticed her gentle smile begin to drop. “What about my parents?” I said. “Are they okay?”

Dr. Parsons placed her hands on mine. “I’m so sorry, Michael. Your mom and dad-- their injuries were just too much.”

My eyes started welling up. “They’re dead?” I asked.

“I’m sorry Michael.”

At this point, the room started to spin, and I closed my eyes, softly crying.
